facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 185 of 1952 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 15, 1948 of Madras High Court in Appeal No. 155 of 1946.

facts.text: Arising out of decree dated October 27, 1945 in Original Suit No. 132 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the decree dated October 27, 1945, in Original Suit No. 132 of 1944. Alladi Kuppuswami and M. S. K. Sastri, for the appellants.

facts.text: Suit filed with sanction of the Collector under s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The suit from which this appeal arises was filed with the sanction of the Collector under s. 92 of the Cc de of Civil Procedure and the plaintiffs alleged that the

facts.text: Purushottam executed and registered a deed of trust on March 17, 1919 creating a trust in respect of his properties.

anchor.surface_text: That is why he executed and registered a deed of trust on March 17, 1919. By this document, a trust in respect of his properties was created and three trustees

facts.text: Three trustees appointed: Purushottam, Mr. Reballa Subbarayudu and Mr. Viswanadha Rao.

anchor.surface_text: By this document, a trust in respect of his properties was created and three trustees were appointed to administer the trust. Purushottam himself was one of these trustees

facts.text: Purushottam's son Ramakrishnayya obstructed the administration of the trust.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that Purushottams son Ramakrishnayya did number approve of this arrangement and he began to obstruct the administration of the trust.

facts.text: Two suits filed by trustees against Ramakrishnayya: O.S. No. 599 of 1919 and O.S. No. 68 of 1920.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this obstructive attitude adopted by Ramakrishnayya, two suits had to be filed by the trustees against Ramakrishnayya and his associates who interfered with the management of the trust. These two suits were O.S. No. 599 of 1919 and O.S. No. 68 of 1920

facts.text: Suits transferred to Sub-Court, Nellore as O.S. No. 39 of 1921 and O.S. No. 67 of 1921.

anchor.surface_text: on the files of the District Munsiffs Court, Kavali, and the District Court, Nellore, respectively. They were subsequently transferred to the Sub-Court, Nellore, and numbered as O.S. No. 39 of 1921 and O.S. No. 67 of 1921

facts.text: Suits ended in a compromise decree.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the hearing of these suits, the two advocates trustees withdrew from the suits leaving the companyduct of the suits solely in charge of Purushottam. Ultimately the two suits ended in a companypromise.

facts.text: Plaintiffs alleged the compromise decree was fraudulent and collusive.

anchor.surface_text: According to the plaint in the present suit out of the which this 1126 appeal has arisen, this companypromise decree was fraudulent and companylusive the object of the parties being to efface the character of the trust properties

facts.text: Purushottam and Ramakrishnayya were dead at the time of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: At the date of this suit both Purushottam and his son Ramakrishnayya were dead. Ramakrishnayyas son Ramalingeswara Rao was therefore impleaded as defendant No.

facts.text: Agreement of sale by defendant No. 1 to defendants 47 and 48 executed on June 7, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1942, an agreement of sale by defendant No. 1 in favour of defendants 47 and 48 was executed and a decree for specific performance was ultimately passed

facts.text: Defendants 47 and 48 impleaded to the suit on January 3, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: It was then that defendants 47 and 48 were impleaded to this suit on January 3, 1944. These defendants substantially adopted the defence raised by the other

facts.text: Trial judge held compromise decree not collusive or fraudulent and binding on the trust, but created a trust.

anchor.surface_text: On the pleadings of the parties, the learned trial judge framed ten issues. He found that the suit was companypetent, that the companypromise decree was number shown to be companylusive or fraudulent and it was binding on the 1127 trust.

facts.text: Trial court decree passed on October 27, 1945 declaring properties trust properties and directing scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, the said companypromise decree itself created a trust in favour of public charities and in respect of the properties which had been allotted by the companypromise decree to the share of Purushottam. [...] This decree was passed on October 27, 1945.

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed appeal of defendants 47 and 48 on December 15, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was taken to the High Court of Madras by defendants 47 and 48. On December 15, 1948, the appeal preferred by defendants 47 and 48 was dismissed and the decree passed by the trial Court was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Supreme Court interlocutory judgment on March 30, 1955 sent case back to High Court of Andhra for findings on two points.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 47 and 48 then preferred the present appeal to this Court. By our interlocutory judgment on March 30, 1955, we sent the case back to the High Court of Andhra with the direction that they should record their findings

facts.text: High Court of Andhra found compromise decree not collusive, binding on trust, and obligation annexed to property.

facts.text: Supreme Court held properties are not subject to public charitable trust but merely burdened or charged with obligation for charities.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the properties companytinue to be the properties of Purushottam until his death and on his death they devolved upon his grandson Ramalingeswara Rao subject always to the burden of performing the charities

facts.text: Appellants conceded properties in their hands subject to charge in favour of charities.

anchor.surface_text: The present, appellants who are in possession of a substantial portion of the properties in suit as alienees have resisted this claim. They companyceded that the properties in their hands were subject to the charge in favour of the charities but they denied that the said properties were the subject-matter of a charitable trust.

facts.text: Purushottam earning and purchasing properties and dedicating them for public charitable purposes since 1896.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint, it was alleged that one Purushottam had been earning and purchasing large properties and endowing and dedicating them for public charitable purpose since 1896.

facts.text: Nine specific charities listed in the 1919 deed of trust.

holdings.text: The properties in suit are not the subject matter of a public charitable trust but are merely burdened or charged with the obligation in favour of the specified charities.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the properties continue to be the properties of Purushottam until his death and on his death they devolved upon his grandson Ramalingeswara Rao subject always to the burden of performing the charities mentioned in the earlier deed of trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of compromise decree cl.1 as a whole shows partial dedication: Purushottam as sole trustee enjoys income per charity necessity without alienation, property passes to grandson subject to charities; inconsistent with complete trust extinguishing private title; distinguished from 1919 deed; supported by Hindu law precedents on complete vs partial dedication.

holdings.text: The compromise decree did not create a public charitable trust in respect of the properties allotted to Purushottam's share.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the learned Judges of the High Court of Madras were in error in construing this clause as evidencing the creation of a public charitable trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 1 language (enjoy till lifetime per necessity, devolve to grandson subject to charities, no guardian for trustee property) retains private title with charge; contrasts with 1919 deed's full dedication; precedents like Maharani Hemanta, Jadu Nath, Pande Har Narayan confirm partial where substantial private benefit or devolution.

holdings.text: The obligation to perform the charities is annexed to the property allotted to Purushottam under the compromise decree and follows the property.

anchor.surface_text: They have held that the obligation in question is annexed to the property that fell to the share of Purushottam under the compromise decree and they have found that the said compromise decree was not collusive and was binding on the trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepting High Court of Andhra finding post-remand; consistent with partial dedication doctrine where charge attaches and follows private property into hands of heirs and alienees.

holdings.text: The compromise decree was not collusive or fraudulent and is binding on the trust.

holdings.text: The compromise decree is binding on the original 1919 trust and plaintiffs are estopped from contending otherwise or that it constituted a breach of trust.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs acquiesced in lower court findings that decree bound trust, did not appeal trial decree or object to remand findings; obtained scheme decree on substituted trust basis; conduct amounts to admission effacing original trust.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs are estopped from reviving the original 1919 trust as unaffected by the compromise decree.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs' failure to appeal lower court holdings on decree's binding effect, acceptance of substituted trust scheme; too late to argue original trust subsists independently.

holdings.text: The properties in the hands of the appellants are subject to the charge in favour of the said charities.

precedents.citation: Maharani Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Gauri Shankar Tewari and Others 1 1940 L.R. 68 I.A. 53, 63

anchor.surface_text: In Maharani Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Gauri Shankar Tewari and Others  1 , Sir George Rankin, who delivered the judgment of the Board has observed, In the usual case of complete dedication made to an idol, for example, the property ceases altogether to belong to the donor, and becomes vested in the idol as a juristic person. Complete relinquishment by the owner of his proprietary right is, however, by

precedents.case_name: Maharani Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Gauri Shankar Tewari
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between complete dedication (property vests in idol, private title extinguished) and partial dedication (no transfer of title, property retains secular character with charge for charity)
precedents.cited_holding: the property ceases altogether to belong to the donor, and becomes vested in the idol as a juristic person. Complete relinquishment by the owner of his proprietary right is, however, by no means the only form of dedication known to Hindu law

precedents.citation: Chairman of the Howrah Municipality v. Khetra Krishna Mitra 1 1906 4 Cal. L.J. 343, 348

anchor.surface_text: From the standpoint of the Hindu law it is not essential to a valid dedication that the legal title should pass from the owner, nor is it inconsistent with an effectual dedication that the owner should continue to make any and all uses of the land which do not interfere with the uses for which it is dedicated per Mookerjee J. in Chairman of the Howrah Municipality v. Khetra Krishna Mitra  1 . The learned Judge has further added that when the dedication is only partial the property in some parts of India might n

precedents.case_name: Chairman of the Howrah Municipality v. Khetra Krishna Mitra
precedents.cited_proposition: Valid partial dedication does not require passing of legal title to charity; owner may continue private uses not interfering with dedicated purpose; property descends alienable with charge
precedents.cited_holding: it is not essential to a valid dedication that the legal title should pass from the owner, nor is it inconsistent with an effectual dedication that the owner should continue to make any and all uses of the land which do not interfere with the uses for which it is dedicated

precedents.citation: Jadu Nath Singh v. Thakur Sita Ramji 2 1917 L.R. 44 I.A. 187, 190

anchor.surface_text: In Jadu Nath Singh v. Thakur Sita Ramji  2  the Privy Council was dealing with a deed of dedication which provided that after the death of the grantor certain female members of his family should succeed him as managers, that half the income should be enjoyed by the managers without power of alienation, that upon the death of the named managers the Government should become manager and the whole net income should then be applied to the expenses of the temple. The Privy Council held that the deed was a valid endowment of the whole property to the temple and that the donor had no rights in it against either the idol or the managers. Dealing with the argument that in the hands of the female members of the grantors family liberty was given to the said members to enjoy half the income, Lord Haldane observed that If the income of the property had been large, a question might have been raised, in the circumstances, as throwing some doubt upon the integrity of the settlers intention, but, as the entire income is only 800 rupees, it is obvious that the payment to these ladies is of the most trifling kind, and certainly not an amount which one would expect in a case of that kind.

precedents.case_name: Jadu Nath Singh v. Thakur Sita Ramji
precedents.cited_proposition: Deed providing for managers enjoying part of income constitutes complete dedication if such enjoyment is trifling relative to total income and intention is to devote whole to charity
precedents.cited_holding: the deed was a valid endowment of the whole property to the temple and that the donor had no rights in it against either the idol or the managers

precedents.citation: Pande, Har Narayan v. Surja Kunwari 1 1921 L.R. I.A. 143

anchor.surface_text: In Pande, Har Narayan v. Surja Kunwari  1 , the Privy Council has observed that in determining whether the will of a Hindu gives the testators estate to an idol subject to the charge in favour of the heirs of the testator or makes the gift to the idol a charge upon the estate, there is no fixed rule depending upon the use of particular terms in the will. The question depends upon the construction of the will as a whole. In this particular case, though the will had provided that the property of the testator shall be considered to be property of a certain idol, there were further provisions which showed that the residue after defraying the expenses of, the temple shall be used by the testators legal heirs to meet their own expenses and it appeared that only a small proportion of the total income could be utilised for the idol whereas a large balance was available to the heirs. On these facts, it was held by the Privy Council that the intention disclosed by the document was that the heirs should take the property subject to the charge for the performance of the religious purposes named in the will.

precedents.case_name: Pande Har Narayan v. Surja Kunwari
precedents.cited_proposition: No fixed rule for determining complete or partial dedication based on particular terms; depends on construction of whole document; substantial private benefit indicates partial charge only
precedents.cited_holding: the intention disclosed by the document was that the heirs should take the property subject to the charge for the performance of the religious purposes named in the will

precedents.citation: Sonatun Bysack v. Sreemutti Juggutsoondree Dossee 2 8 Moo. I. A. 66

anchor.surface_text: Lord Shaw, who delivered the judgment of the Board, cited with approval the earlier observations of Turner L. J. in Sonatun Bysack v. Sreemutti Juggutsoondree Dossee  2 . Turner L. J. had stated although the will purports to begin with an absolute gift in favour of the idol, it is plain that the testator contemplated that there was to be some distribution of the property according as events might turn out and that he did not intend to give this property absolutely to the idol seems to their Lordships to be clear from the directions

precedents.case_name: Sonatun Bysack v. Sreemutti Juggutsoondree Dossee
precedents.cited_proposition: Will purporting absolute gift to idol but containing provisions for private distribution does not effect complete transfer to idol
precedents.cited_holding: although the will purports to begin with an absolute gift in favour of the idol, it is plain that the testator contemplated that there was to be some distribution of the property according as events might turn out and that he did not intend to give this property absolutely to the idol

precedents.citation: Gopal Lal Sett v. Purna Chandra Basak 1 1921 L.R. 49 I.A. 100

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Gopal Lal Sett v. Purna Chandra Basak 1 , the Privy Council held that the will of the Hindu testatrix with which they were concerned in this case conferred the properties specified on the grandson charged with the maintenance of the worship but that no shebaitship was created. The will in question had provided that out of the income of the specified property, her grandson should perform the worship of certain family idols and that he should be in charge of the worship. The will contained no gift, express or implied, to the idols, and there was no provision for the worship after the death of the grandson.

precedents.case_name: Gopal Lal Sett v. Purna Chandra Basak
precedents.cited_proposition: Bequest directing grandson to perform worship from income creates charge on property for charity but no shebaitship or complete dedication if no gift to idol and no provision post-death
precedents.cited_holding: the will ... conferred the properties specified on the grandson charged with the maintenance of the worship but that no shebaitship was created
